Award.AwardTitle: CBMS Conference: Elastic Functional and Shape Data Analysis (EFSDA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award provides support for the CBMS Conference: Elastic Functional and Shape Data Analysis (EFSDA), which will be held in July 16-20, 2018 at The Ohio State University in Columbus, OH. The primary lecturer is Professor Anuj Srivastava from the Department of Statistics at Florida State University. The conference will feature a lecture series on elastic methods for statistical analysis of functional and shape data, using tools from Riemannian geometry, Hilbert space methods, and computational science. The main focus of this conference will be on geometric approaches, especially on using elastic Riemannian metrics with desired invariance properties, and square-root representations of shape that have proven to simplify computations. These approaches enable joint registration and statistical analysis of functional data, and are termed elastic for that reason. The statistical goals include comparisons, summarization, clustering, modeling, and testing of functional and shape data objects. The proposed tools for statistical analysis of functional and shape data have broad applications in almost all branches of science. Any promotion of education, training, and collaboration in this cutting-edge research area will have a strong impact on the community. The audience for this workshop will include early career researchers from statistics, applied mathematics, engineering, computer science and biological sciences. By training and educating researchers in an important STEM area, this effort will facilitate future interdisciplinary collaborations amongst participants.

Recent years have seen a tremendous advancement in the use of Riemannian geometry in statistical data analysis, especially in shape analysis. EFSDA brings together tools from diverse disciplines, such as geometry, statistics, functional data analysis, computational science, and application domains, to develop a broad and comprehensive package of solutions. On one hand, it poses fundamental mathematical questions, including existence and uniqueness of optimal functional matching, and on the other, it provides efficient computational implementations for problems dealing with alignment, dimension reduction, and statistical modeling of functional and shape data. Given the proliferation of functional data in all scientific disciplines, these tools will help address important and urgent data analysis needs. The classroom-style lectures will be enhanced by multiple discussion sessions. For the conference webpage, please see https://stat.osu.edu/cbms-efsda.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the organization of a five day CMBS Conference on Elastic Functional and Shape Data Analysis (EFSDA) at The Ohio State University between July 16-20, 2018. Given the proliferation of functional and shape data in all scientific disciplines, ranging from medicine to chemistry, Elastic Functional and Shape Data Analysis tools have the potential to address important and urgent data analysis needs. Overall, this conference was very timely, and was unique in terms of the focus areas, pedagogical style, and interdisciplinary composition of the participants. By training and educating young researchers in this important STEM area, this conference facilitated future interdisciplinary collaborations among participants. The conference was hosted at the Mathematical Biosciences Institute and included five distinguished lecturers: Prof. Anuj Srivastava (primary lecturer), Prof. Eric Klassen, Prof. Karthik Bharath, Prof. Laurent Younes, and Prof. Veerabhadran Baladandayuthapani. These lecturers delivered ten two hour lectures on the following topics: (1) Introduction and Background, (2) Elastic Functional Data Analysis, (3) Elastic Shape Analysis of Curves, (4) Fundamental Mathematical Formulations, Recent Progress and Open Problems, (5) Elastic Shape Analysis of Surfaces, (6) Statistical Models, (7) Generalizations of the Square Root Velocity Framework to Trajectories on Manifolds, (8) Introduction to Metric Registration, (9) Bayesian Models for Richly Structured Data in Biomedicine, and (10) Geometry-based Brain Structural Connectome Analysis. In addition to the lectures, Prof. Sebastian Kurtek led a Matlab tutorial session with many hands-on examples. There were also multiple opportunities for discussion that were built into the lectures. All of the lectures and associated videos are available to the public at the following webpage: https://www.asc.ohio-state.edu/kurtek.1/cbms.html; this webpage also includes a Conference Introduction and Motivation file, relevant Matlab packages with well-known datasets and detailed documentation, and a list of relevant reading materials with links. During each day of the conference, a hot breakfast was served in the morning with coffee breaks during the two hour sessions. This stimulated discussion between conference participants. There was also a reception on the first afternoon of the conference and a pizza lunch at the end of the conference. In addition to the lecturers and organizers, there were a total of 37 registered participants (there were additional local participants that attended many of the lectures but did not officially register for the conference) representing 21 institutions from around the world (there were six participants from outside of the United States) and six different types of departments (e.g., Statistics, Biostatistics, Mathematics, Computer Science, etc.). 14 of the registered participants were women, 26 were graduate students, three were postdoctoral researchers, five were junior faculty (Assistant Professor level) and three were senior faculty (Associate Professor or Professor level). Among the 41 participants, 28 were provided with travel funding by this project, with priority given to graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and junior faculty.
